Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Program in Chemical Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Vanderbilt University, located in Nashville, TN, will support the training of 10 undergraduate students for an immersive 10-week research experience during the summers of 2021-2023. The program provides research opportunities in chemical biology within the laboratories of seasoned Vanderbilt faculty mentors, as well as exposure to new areas of research through interdisciplinary scientific seminars. In an effort to prepare and support students for their future scientific careers, a complementary professional development seminar series is included in the summer research experience and covers essential topics such as research ethics, safety training, abstract writing, and poster presentation techniques. Seminars on applying to graduate school, seeking out funding opportunities and a separate GRE preparation class are also available to participants to help prepare them for post-secondary education opportunities. Ultimately, this program aims to promote and train a diverse body of students for careers in the scientific workforce by providing them with immersive interdisciplinary research experiences.

The Vanderbilt chemical biology-themed REU program aims to recruit a diverse group of undergraduate students who are majoring in chemistry, biochemistry and biology for careers in trans-disciplinary chemical or biochemical research. Research topics include proteomics, structural biology, chemical synthesis, and synthetic biology. Diverse role models, including alumni and faculty, offer pictures of success pursuing research directions that integrate human health and basic science. Through personalized mentoring and an authentic research experience, this program is designed to help students develop the understanding and tenacity necessary for a career in cutting-edge chemical biology research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU in Chemical Biology at Vanderbilt trained students in interdisciplinary research in the area of chemical biology within the laboratories of Vanderbilt faculty working at the cutting edge of the field. The program was designed to provide research experiences to students in several ongoing projects in chemical biology, as well as exposure to new areas of research through scientific seminars. Our professional development seminar series prepared the students for their future scientific careers, covering topics such as research ethics, safety training, abstract writing, and poster presentation techniques. The program has been successful by all key measures: it has recruited and supported a diverse group of undergraduate students majoring in chemistry, biochemistry, and biology. They have made significant contributions to the scientific literature, and most have continued in the STEM workforce. We have worked to identify the next generation of young talent with great potential for chemical or biochemical research careers. In this funding cycle, the program had 10 students in the summer of 2021, 9 in 2022, and 11 students in 2023, all in person during the pandemic.  The majority of those who have graduated have gone on to graduate research careers: Because our REU participants are from diverse backgrounds, and so many are choosing a career in science, our program is helping to diversify the scientific workforce, an important national goal. For example, we invested in bringing community college students into our program. Two of the thirty students this cycle were from a local community college and transferred to local four-year colleges.  More broadly, our program had an essential impact on the national scientific enterprise in multiple ways. We provide students with valuable early research experiences that many would not have in their home institutions. These experiences play a critical role in a student's decision to pursue a career in science. Furthermore, we are providing mentors and role models to these students. Likely, many never had an opportunity to interact with a member of the scientific research community, and their understanding of the true depth and breadth of research may be naive or even anachronistic when considering professional career prospects that begin with chemistry and chemical biology. These intensely mentored research experiences allowed students to see that they can be successful in research and build the beginning of a lifelong support network that will accelerate them toward a research-based scientific career.
